<rect width="8" height="8" fill="currentColor"/>
</svg></div><a href="/de/blog" class="back-blog_link w-inline-block"><div class="text-size-small text-color-grey">Blog</div></a><link rel="prefetch" href="/de/blog"/><div class="text-eyebrow">/</div><a href="#" class="tag-pill-blog w-inline-block"><div class="w-dyn-bind-empty"></div></a><div class="text-eyebrow">/</div><div class="text-size-small text-color-grey">August 22, 2022</div><div class="eyebrow-reveal-div"></div></div><div class="spacer-small"></div><h1 class="blog_heading1">Emotet Resurgence: Cross-Industry Analysis</h1><div class="spacer-small"></div><div class="text-color-grey">Technical insights on the Emotet resurgence in 2022 across various client environments, industries, and regions.</div><div class="spacer-medium"></div><div class="blog_show-responsive-devices"><div class="flex-wrap-horizontal"><div class="author_blog-wrapper"><div class="w-dyn-list"><div role="list" class="vertical _20-grid-padding w-dyn-items"><div role="listitem" class="w-dyn-item"><a href="/de/people/eugene-chua" class="vertical _20-grid-padding w-inline-block w-condition-invisible"><div class="horizontal _8px-gap"><div class="author_image-wrapper"><img src="" loading="lazy" alt="" class="author_image w-dyn-bind-empty"/></div><div class="author_text-wrapper"><div class="text-size-small text-weight-medium">Written by</div><div class="text-size-small text-weight-medium">Eugene Chua</div><div class="text-size-tiny text-color-grey">Cyber Security Analyst</div></div></div></a></div></div></div></div></div><div class="flex-wrap-horizontal-inside-soc"><div class="inside-soc_sidebar"><div class="pixel-eyebrow_wrapper"><div class="icon-embed-custom is-pixel white w-embed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="100%" height="100%" viewBox="0 0 8 8" fill="none" preserveAspectRatio="xMidYMid meet" aria-hidden="true" role="img">
<rect width="8" height="8" fill="currentColor"/>
</svg></div><div class="text-eyebrow white">Inside the SOC</div><div class="eyebrow-reveal-div"></div></div><div class="text-size-small text-is-white inside-soc">Darktrace cyber analysts are world-class experts in threat intelligence, threat hunting and incident response, and provide 24/7 SOC support to thousands of Darktrace customers around the globe. <em>Inside the SOC</em> is exclusively authored by these experts, providing analysis of cyber incidents and threat trends, based on real-world experience in the field.<br/></div><div class="inside-soc_author"><div class="w-dyn-list"><div role="list" class="w-dyn-items"><div role="listitem" class="w-dyn-item"><div><div><div class="author_image-wrapper"><img src="" loading="lazy" alt="" class="author_image w-dyn-bind-empty"/></div><div class="author_text-wrapper up"><div class="text-size-small text-weight-medium text-is-white">Written by</div><div class="text-size-small text-weight-medium text-is-white">Eugene Chua</div><div class="text-size-tiny text-color-light-grey">Cyber Security Analyst</div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="spacer-small"></div><div class="blog_social-wrapper show_responsive-device"><div class="social-text-wrapper"><div class="pixel-eyebrow_wrapper"><div class="icon-embed-custom is-pixel w-embed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="100%" height="100%" viewBox="0 0 8 8" fill="none" preserveAspectRatio="xMidYMid meet" aria-hidden="true" role="img">
<rect width="8" height="8" fill="currentColor"/>
</svg></div><div class="text-eyebrow">Share</div><div class="eyebrow-reveal-div"></div></div></div><div class="social-links_wrapper"><a data-social="linkedin" href="#" target="_blank" alt="" class="blog_social-icon"/></a></div></div></div></div><div id="w-node-_5f448767-4c1a-c3e0-7f18-ed9ca986ddb5-c9d8d661" class="blog-image-post-wrapper is_new-blog"><img src="" loading="lazy" w-condition-invisible"/><img srcset="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c51fcd1ebb3a9c05c8_SOC-Integration-p-500.webp 500w, srcset="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c501dad065b00001fe_SOC-Threat%20Research-p-500.webp 500w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c501dad065b00001fe_SOC-Threat%20Research.webp 1400w" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c501dad065b00001fe_SOC-Threat%20Research.webp" alt="Default blog image" class="blog-header-image cover"/><img srcset="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c4759b8597405a0e9b_SOC-Indcident%20Analysis-p-500.webp 500w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c4759b8597405a0e9b_SOC-Indcident%20Analysis-p-800.webp 800w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c4759b8597405a0e9b_SOC-Indcident%20Analysis-p-1080.webp 1080w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c4759b8597405a0e9b_SOC-Indcident%20Analysis.webp 1400w" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c4759b8597405a0e9b_SOC-Indcident%20Analysis.webp" alt="Default blog image" class="blog-header-image cover w-condition-invisible"/><img srcset="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c3eacf9475abd31fbf_SOC-Bytesize%20Analysis-p-500.webp 500w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c3eacf9475abd31fbf_SOC-Bytesize%20Analysis-p-800.webp 800w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c3eacf9475abd31fbf_SOC-Bytesize%20Analysis-p-1080.webp 1080w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c3eacf9475abd31fbf_SOC-Bytesize%20Analysis.webp 1400w" loading="lazy" sizes="100vw" src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/64d3b3c3eacf9475abd31fbf_SOC-Bytesize%20Analysis.webp" alt="Default blog image" class="blog-header-image cover w-condition-invisible"/><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/62ad3aca1401273fd522699d_Photo.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="Default blog image" class="blog-header-image cover w-condition-invisible"/><div class="blog-image-overlay"></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><div class="all-blog-main-content"><section class="section_blog-content"><div class="padding-section-small padding-is_responsive-device"><div class="padding-global"><div class="container-large"><div class="main_blog-component"><div id="w-node-_5b477458-bc76-0e44-6e34-437a4c058fcd-c9d8d661" class="blog-article_main"><div class="blog-content-block"><div class="floating-date"><div class="date-number">22</div><div class="text-size-small">Aug 2022</div></div><div class="divider-line"></div><div class="text-rich-text is-blog w-richtext"><h3>Introduction</h3><p>Last year provided further evidence that the cyber threat landscape remains both complex and challenging to predict. Between uncertain attribution, novel exploits and rapid malware developments, it is becoming harder to know where to focus security efforts. One of the largest surprises of 2021 was the re-emergence of the infamous Emotet botnet. This is an example of a campaign that ignored industry verticals or regions and seemingly targeted companies indiscriminately. Only 10 months after the Emotet takedown by law enforcement agencies in January, new Emotet activities in November were discovered by security researchers. These continued into the first quarter of 2022, a period which this blog will explore through findings from the Darktrace Threat Intel Unit.Â </p><p>Dating back to 2019, Emotet was known to deliver Trickbot payloads which ultimately deployed Ryuk ransomware strains on compromised devices. This interconnectivity highlighted the hydra-like nature of threat groups wherein eliminating one (even with full-scale law enforcement intervention) would not rule them out as a threat nor indicate that the threat landscape would be any more secure.Â </p><p>When Emotet resurged, as expected, one of the initial infection vectors involved leveraging existing Trickbot infrastructure. However, unlike the original attacks, it featured a brand new phishing campaign.</p><figure style="max-width:1960pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68b885c2b3376168634e79d8_67ea7312984e601f71919603_6304aa12fbd531cd81579949_emotet%252520figure%2525201.avif" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption>Figure 1: Distribution of observed Emotet activities across Darktrace deployments</figcaption></figure><p>Although similar to the original Emotet infections, the new wave of infections has been classified into two categories: Epochs 4 and 5. These had several key differences compared to Epochs 1 to 3. Within Darktraceâs global deployments, Emotet compromises associated to Epoch 4 appeared to be the most prevalent. Affected customer environments were seen within a large range of countries (Figure 1) and industry verticals such as manufacturing and supply chain, hospitality and travel, public administration, technology and telecoms and healthcare. Company demographics and size did not appear to be a targeting factor as affected customers had varying employee counts ranging from less than 250, to over 5000.</p><h3>Key differences between Epochs 1-3 vs 4-5</h3><p>Based on wider security research into the innerworkings of the Emotet exploits, several key differences were identified between Epochs 4/5 and its predecessors. The newer epochs used:</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  A different Microsoft document format (OLE vs XML-based).</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  A different encryption algorithm for communication. The new epochs used Elliptic Curve Cryptograph (ECC) [1] with public encryption keys contained in the C2 configuration file [2]. This was different from the previous Rivest-Shamir-Adleman (RSA) key encryption method.</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Control Flow Flattening was used as an obfuscation technique to make detection and reverse engineering more difficult. This is done by hiding a programâs control flow [3].</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  New C2 infrastructure was observed as C2 communications were directed to over 230 unique IPs all associated to the new Epochs 4 and 5.</p><p>In addition to the new Epoch 4 and 5 features, Darktrace detected unsurprising similarities in those deployments affected by the renewed campaign. This included self-signed SSL connections to Emotetâs new infrastructure as well as malware spam activities to multiple rare external endpoints. Preceding these outbound communications, devices across multiple deployments were detected downloading Emotet-associated payloads (algorithmically generated DLL files).</p><h3>Emotet Resurgence Campaign</h3><figure style="max-width:902pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68b885c2b3376168634e7a01_67ea7311984e601f719195d7_62fe6d8ab4e1dc31447ec032_Picture%2525201.avif" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption>Figure 2: Darktraceâs Detection Timeline for Emotet Epoch 4 and 5 compromises</figcaption></figure><p><strong>1. Initial Compromise</strong></p><p>The initial point of entry for the resurgence activity was almost certainly via Trickbot infrastructure or a successful phishing attack (Figure 2). Following the initial intrusion, the malware strain begins to download payloads via macro-ladened files which are used to spawn PowerShell for subsequent malware downloads.</p><p>Following the downloads, malicious communication with Emotetâs C2 infrastructure was observed alongside activities from the spam module. Within Darktrace, key techniques were observed and documented below.</p><p><strong>2. Establish Foothold: Binary Dynamic-link library (.dll) with algorithmically generated filenamesÂ </strong></p><p>EmotetÂ payloads are polymorphic and contain algorithmically generated filenames . Within deployments, HTTP GET requests involving a suspicious hostname,Â www[.]arkpp[.]com, and EmotetÂ related samples such as those seen below were observed:</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  hpixQfCoJb0fS1.dll (SHA256 hash: 859a41b911688b00e104e9c474fc7aaf7b1f2d6e885e8d7fbf11347bc2e21eaa)</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  M0uZ6kd8hnzVUt2BNbRzRFjRoz08WFYfPj2.dll (SHA256 hash: 9fbd590cf65cbfb2b842d46d82e886e3acb5bfecfdb82afc22a5f95bda7dd804)</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  TpipJHHy7P.dll (SHA256 hash: 40060259d583b8cf83336bc50cc7a7d9e0a4de22b9a04e62ddc6ca5dedd6754b)</p><p>These DLL files likely represent the distribution of Emotet loaders which depends on windows processes such as rundll32[.]exe and regsvr32[.]exe to execute.Â </p><p><strong>3. Establish Foothold: Outbound SSL connections toÂ EmotetÂ C2 serversÂ </strong></p><p>A clear network indicator of compromise for Emotetâs C2 communication involved self-signed SSL using certificate issuers and subjects which matched âCN=example[.]com,OU=ITÂ Department,O=GlobalÂ Security,L=London,ST=London,C=GBâ , and a common JA3 client fingerprint (72a589da586844d7f0818ce684948eea). The primary C2 communications were seen involving infrastructures classified as Epoch 4 rather than 5. Despite encryption in the communication content, network contextual connection details were sufficient for the detection of the C2 activities (Figure 3).</p><figure style="max-width:1073pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68b885c2b3376168634e7a4a_67ea7313984e601f7191963f_6304af6ffbd5317d1657d1f9_Picture%2525201.avif" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption>Figure 3: UI Model Breach logs on download and outbound SSL activities.</figcaption></figure><p><em>Outbound SSL and SMTP connections on TCP ports 25, 465, 587Â </em></p><p>An anomalous user agent such as, âMicrosoft Outlook 15.0â, was observed being used for SMTP connections with some subject lines of the outbound emails containing Base64-encoded strings. In addition, this JA3 client fingerprint (37cdab6ff1bd1c195bacb776c5213bf2) was commonly seen from the SSL connections. Based on the set of malware spam hostnames observed across at least 10 deployments, the majority of the TLDs were .jp, .com, .net, .mx, with the Japanese TLD being the most common (Figure 4).</p><figure style="max-width:1439pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68b885c1b3376168634e79c8_67ea7311984e601f719195d0_6304afda0ef53f424636f0de_Picture%2525201.avif" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption>Figure 4: Malware Spam TLDs observed in outbound SSL and SMTP</figcaption></figure><p>Â Plaintext spam content generated from the spam module were seen in PCAPs (Figure 5). Examples of clear phishing or spam indicators included 1) mismatched personal header and email headers, 2) unusual reply chain and recipient references in the subject line, and 3) suspicious compressed file attachments, e.g. Electronic form[.]zip.</p><figure style="max-width:627pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68b885c2b3376168634e7a53_67ea7313984e601f71919642_6304b022471a7f43db414bf0_Picture%2525201.avif" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption>Figure 5: Example of PCAP associated to SPAM Module</figcaption></figure><p><strong>4. Accomplish Mission</strong></p><p>Â The Emotet resurgence also showed through secondary compromises involving anomalous SMB drive writes related to CobaltStrike. This consistently included the following JA3 hash (72a589da586844d7f0818ce684948eea) seen in SSL activities as well as SMB writes involving the svchost.exe file.</p><h3>Darktrace Detection</h3><p>Â The key DETECT models used to identify Emotet Resurgence activities were focused on determining possible C2. These included:</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Suspicious SSL Activity</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Suspicious Self-Signed SSL</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Rare External SSL Self-Signed</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Possible Outbound Spam</p><p>File-focused models were also beneficial and included:</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Zip or Gzip from Rare External Location</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  EXE from Rare External Location</p><p>Darktraceâs detection capabilities can also be shown through a sample of case studies identified during the Threat Research teamâs investigations.</p><h3>Case StudiesÂ </h3><p>Darktraceâs detection of Emotet activities was not limited by industry verticals or company sizing. Although there were many similar features seen across the new epoch, each incident displayed varying techniques from the campaign. This is shown in two client environments below:</p><p>When investigating a large customer environment within the public administration sector, 16 different devices were detected making 52,536 SSL connections with the example[.]com issuer. Devices associated with this issuer were mainly seen breaching the same Self-Signed and Spam DETECT models. Although anomalous incoming octet-streams were observed prior to this SSL, there was no clear relation between the downloads and the Emotet C2 connections. Despite the total affected devices occupying only a small portion of the total network, Darktrace analysts were able to filter against the much larger network ânoiseâ and locate detailed evidence of compromise to notify the customer.</p><p>Darktrace also identified new Emotet activities in much smaller customer environments. Looking at a company in the healthcare and pharmaceutical sector, from mid-March 2022 a single internal device was detected making an HTTP GET request to the host arkpp[.]com involving the algorithmically-generated DLL, TpipJHHy7P.dll with the SHA256 hash: 40060259d583b8cf83336bc50cc7a7d9e0a4de22b9a04e62ddc6ca5dedd6754b (Figure 6).Â </p><figure style="max-width:1678pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68b885c2b3376168634e7a4d_67ea7315984e601f71919668_6304b07ce54ef640ffeb3033_Picture%2525201.avif" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption>Figure 6: A screenshot from VirusTotal, showing that the SHA256 hash has been flagged as malicious by other security vendors.</figcaption></figure><p>After the sample was downloaded, the device contacted a large number of endpoints that had never been contacted by devices on the network. The endpoints were contacted over ports 443, 8080, and 7080 involving Emotet related IOCs and the same SSL certificate mentioned previously. Malware spam activities were also observed during a similar timeframe.</p><p>Â The Emotet case studies above demonstrate how autonomous detection of an anomalous sequence of activities - without depending on conventional rules and signatures - can reveal significant threat activities. Though possible staged payloads were only seen in a proportion of the affected environments, the following outbound C2 and malware spam activities involving many endpoints and ports were sufficient for the detection of Emotet.</p><p>Â If present, in both instances Darktraceâs Autonomous Response technology, RESPOND, would recommend or implement surgical actions to precisely target activities associated with the staged payload downloads, outgoing C2 communications, and malware spam activities. Additionally, restriction to the devicesâ normal pattern of life will prevent simultaneously occurring malicious activities while enabling the continuity of normal business operations.</p><h3>Â ConclusionÂ </h3><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  The technical differences between past and present Emotet strains emphasizes the versatility of malicious threat actors and the need for a security solution that is not reliant on signatures.</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Darktraceâs visibility and unique behavioral detection continues to provide visibility to network activities related to the novel Emotet strain without reliance on rules and signatures. Key examples include the C2 connections to new Emotet infrastructure.</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Looking ahead, detection of C2 establishment using suspicious DLLs will prevent further propagation of the Emotet strains across networks.</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Darktraceâs AI detection and response will outpace conventional post compromise research involving the analysis of Emotet strains through static and dynamic code analysis, followed by the implementation of rules and signatures.</p><p><em>Thanks to Paul Jennings and Hanah Darley for their contributions to this blog.</em></p><h3>Appendices</h3><p><strong>Model breaches</strong></p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous Connection / Anomalous SSL without SNI to New ExternalÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous Connection / Application Protocol on Uncommon PortÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous Connection / Multiple Connections to New External TCP PortÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous Connection / Multiple Failed Connections to Rare EndpointÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous Connection / Multiple HTTP POSTs to Rare HostnameÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous Connection / Possible Outbound SpamÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous Connection / Rare External SSL Self-SignedÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous Connection / Repeated Rare External SSL Self-SignedÂ Â Â Â Â Â </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous Connection / Suspicious Expired SSLÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous Connection / Suspicious Self-Signed SSL</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous File / Anomalous Octet Stream (No User Agent)Â </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous File / Zip orÂ GzipÂ from Rare External LocationÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Anomalous File / EXE from Rare External Location</p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Compromise / Agent Beacon to New EndpointÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Compromise / Beacon to Young EndpointÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Compromise / Beaconing Activity To External RareÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Compromise / New or Repeated to Unusual SSL PortÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Compromise / Repeating Connections Over 4 DaysÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Compromise / Slow Beaconing Activity To External RareÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Compromise / SSL Beaconing to Rare DestinationÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Compromise / Suspicious BeaconingÂ BehaviourÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Compromise / Suspicious Spam ActivityÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Compromise / Suspicious SSL ActivityÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Compromise / Sustained SSL or HTTP IncreaseÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Device / Initial Breach Chain CompromiseÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Device / Large Number of Connections to New EndpointsÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Device / Long Agent Connection to New EndpointÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Device / New User AgentÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Device / New User Agent and New IPÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Device / SMB SessionÂ BruteforceÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Device / Suspicious DomainÂ </p><p>Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â  Device / Suspicious SMB Scanning ActivityÂ </p><figure style="max-width:1120pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68b885c2b3376168634e7a04_67ea7311984e601f719195e0_6304b12677c4920e1d0b95ad_new%252520emotet%252520mitre.avif" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div></figure><p>â</p><figure style="max-width:1120pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68b885c2b3376168634e7a07_67ea7311984e601f719195e6_6304b14398651c26b67cb0a0_new%252520emotet%252520IOCs%2525201.avif" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div></figure><figure style="max-width:1120pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68b885c2b3376168634e7a34_67ea7315984e601f7191966b_6304b1572f0d2b7a0df0829a_new%252520emotet%252520IOCs%2525202.avif" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div></figure><figure style="max-width:1120pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68b885c2b3376168634e7a50_67ea7316984e601f7191967b_6304b161fe4eadf388bdfe75_new%252520emotet%252520IOCs%2525203.avif" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div></figure><p><em>For Darktrace customers who want to know more about using Darktrace to triage Emotet, refer </em><a href="https://customerportal.darktrace.com/inside-the-soc/get-article/226"><em>here</em></a><em> for an exclusive supplement to this blog.</em></p><p><strong>References</strong></p><p>[1] <a href="https://blog.lumen.com/emotet-redux/">https://blog.lumen.com/emotet-redux/</a></p><p>[2] <a href="https://blogs.vmware.com/security/2022/03/emotet-c2-configuration-extraction-and-analysis.html">https://blogs.vmware.com/security/2022/03/emotet-c2-configuration-extraction-and-analysis.html</a></p><p>[3] class="spacer-medium"></div><div class="blog-cta-report w-condition-invisible"><div class="background-color-black"><div class="z-index-1"><div class="padding-global"><div class="padding-section-xsmall"><div class="w-layout-grid blog-report_cta"><div class="blog-cta_text-wrapper"><h3 class="blog-cta_header w-dyn-bind-empty"></h3><p class="blog-cta_text Novel Attacks</div><div class="text-small-text">Jun 21, 2024</div></div></a></div><div role="listitem" class="w-dyn-item"><a href="/de/blog/the-state-of-ai-in-cybersecurity-unveiling-global-insights-from-1-800-security-practitioners" class="horizontal align-center w-inline-block"><div class="blog-sidebar-number"><div class="blog-number">4</div></div><div class="_20-left-padding"><div class="text-size-regular wrap">The State of AI in Cybersecurity: Unveiling Global Insights from 1,800 Security Practitioners </div><div class="text-small-text">Apr 9, 2024</div></div></a></div><div role="listitem" class="w-dyn-item"><a href="/de/blog/the-state-of-ai-in-cybersecurity-the-impact-of-ai-on-cybersecurity-solutions" class="horizontal align-center w-inline-block"><div class="blog-sidebar-number"><div class="blog-number">5</div></div><div class="_20-left-padding"><div class="text-size-regular wrap">The State of AI in Cybersecurity: The Impact of AI on Cybersecurity Solutions</div><div class="text-small-text">May 13, 2024</div></div></a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="container w-condition-invisible w-container"><div class="t100 b100 hide"><h2 class="heading-style-h2 _32pt b20">More in this series</h2><div class="w-dyn-list"><div class="w-dyn-empty"><div>No items found.</div></div></div></div></div><div class="related-blog_section"><div class="background-color-grey"><div class="padding-global"><div class="padding-section-small"><div class="container-large"><div class="max-width-large"><div class="pixel-eyebrow_wrapper"><div class="icon-embed-custom is-pixel w-embed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="100%" height="100%" viewBox="0 0 8 8" fill="none" preserveAspectRatio="xMidYMid meet" aria-hidden="true" role="img">

</svg></div><div class="text-eyebrow">Continue reading</div><div class="eyebrow-reveal-div"></div></div><div class="spacer-medium"></div></div><div class="blog35_component"><div class="blog35_list-wrapper w-dyn-list"><div class="w-dyn-empty"><div>No items found.</div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><section class="section_blogs-continued"><div class="padding-global"><div class="container-large"><div class="contiuned-blog-post-wrap hide"><div class="w-dyn-list"><div role="list" class="continue-reading-blogs-cl w-dyn-items"><div role="listitem" class="w-dyn-item"><div class="padding-section-small"><div class="blog-header"><div id="w-node-_6a4e4cbc-bd07-c860-591e-a3d80472f974-c9d8d661" class="blog-header-title"><div><div><div class="pixel-eyebrow_wrapper"><div class="icon-embed-custom w-embed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="100%" height="100%" viewBox="0 0 8 8" fill="none" preserveAspectRatio="xMidYMid meet" aria-hidden="true" role="img">
<rect width="8" height="8" fill="currentColor"/>
</svg></div><h2 class="text-eyebrow">Blog</h2><div class="text-eyebrow">/</div><h2 class="text-eyebrow">Email</h2><div class="text-eyebrow">/</div><h2 class="text-eyebrow">September 30, 2025</h2><div class="eyebrow-reveal-div"></div></div><div class="spacer-small"></div></div></div><h2 class="heading-style-h2">Out of Character: Detecting Vendor Compromise and Trusted Relationship Abuse with Darktrace</h2></div><div id="w-node-_2561d5d9-fcb0-d673-7045-e0de5fb2172b-c9d8d661" class="blog-image-post-wrapper margin-0"><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc570b21f4e95e10bd7c3f_649aad021b3f375a9c9729c6_GettyImages-1400563623.webp" loading="lazy" alt="vendor email compromise" sizes="100vw" srcset="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc570b21f4e95e10bd7c3f_649aad021b3f375a9c9729c6_GettyImages-1400563623-p-500.webp 500w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc570b21f4e95e10bd7c3f_649aad021b3f375a9c9729c6_GettyImages-1400563623-p-800.webp 800w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc570b21f4e95e10bd7c3f_649aad021b3f375a9c9729c6_GettyImages-1400563623-p-1080.webp 1080w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc570b21f4e95e10bd7c3f_649aad021b3f375a9c9729c6_GettyImages-1400563623-p-1600.webp 1600w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc570b21f4e95e10bd7c3f_649aad021b3f375a9c9729c6_GettyImages-1400563623-p-2000.webp 2000w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc570b21f4e95e10bd7c3f_649aad021b3f375a9c9729c6_GettyImages-1400563623.webp 2121w" class="blog-header-image cover"/><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/62d845d8a4c357036c43d980_Blog%20Post%20Image.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="Default blog image" class="blog-header-image cover w-condition-invisible"/><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/62ad3aca1401273fd522699d_Photo.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="Default blog image" class="blog-header-image cover w-condition-invisible"/><div class="blog-image-overlay max-height-300"></div></div></div></div><div class="blog-article-grid"><div class="vertical align-left max-w-720 bottom-padding-40 bottom-border-grey"><div class="text-rich-text truncate is-blog w-richtext"><h2>What is Vendor Email Compromise?</h2><p><a href="https://www.darktrace.com/blog/vendor-pretender-detecting-a-vendor-email-compromise-in-the-wild">Vendor Email Compromise (VEC) </a>refers to an attack where actors breach a third-party provider to exploit their access, relationships, or systems for malicious purposes. The initially compromised entities are often the targetâs existing partners, though this can extend to any organization or individual the target is likely to trust. </p><p>It<strong> </strong>sits at the intersection of <a href="/de/solutions/supply-chain-attack">supply chain attacks</a> and <a href="/de/solutions/business-email-compromise">business email compromise (BEC),</a> blending technical exploitation with trust-based deception. Attackers often infiltrate existing conversations, leveraging AI to mimic tone and avoid common spelling and grammar pitfalls. Malicious content is typically hosted on otherwise reputable file sharing platforms, meaning any shared links initially seem harmless. </p><p>While techniques to achieve initial access may have evolved, the goals remain familiar. Threat actors harvest credentials, launch subsequent phishing campaigns, attempt to redirect invoice payments for financial gain, and exfiltrate sensitive corporate data. </p><h2>Why traditional defenses fall short</h2><p>These subtle and sophisticated email attacks pose unique challenges for defenders. Few busy people would treat an ongoing conversation with a trusted contact with the same level of suspicion as an email from the CEO requesting âURGENT ASSISTANCE!â Unfortunately, many traditional <a href="https://www.darktrace.com/cyber-ai-glossary/secure-email-gateway-seg">secure email gateways (SEGs) </a>struggle with this too. Detecting an out-of-character email, when it does not obviously appear out of character, is a complex challenge. Itâs hardly surprising, then, that 83% of organizations have experienced a security incident involving third-party vendors [1]. Â </p><p>This article explores how Darktrace detected four different vendor compromise campaigns for a single customer, within a two-week period in 2025. Â Darktrace / EMAIL successfully identified the subtle indicators that these seemingly benign emails from trusted senders were, in fact, malicious. Due to the configuration of Darktrace / EMAIL in this customerâs environment, it was unable to take action against the malicious emails. However, if fully enabled to take Autonomous Response, it would have held all offending emails identified.</p><h2>How does Darktrace detect vendor compromise?</h2><p>The answer lies at the core of how Darktrace operates: anomaly detection. Rather than relying on known malicious rules or signatures, Darktrace learns what ânormalâ looks like for an environment, then looks for anomalies across a wide range of metrics. Despite the resourcefulness of the threat actors involved in this case, Darktrace identified many anomalies across these campaigns.</p><h3>Different campaigns, common traits</h3><p>A wide variety of approaches was observed. Individuals, shared mailboxes and external contractors were all targeted. Two emails originated from compromised current vendors, while two came from unknown compromised organizations - one in an associated industry. The sender organizations were either familiar or, at the very least, professional in appearance, with no unusual alphanumeric strings or suspicious top-level domains (TLDs). Subject line, such as âNew Approved Statement From [REDACTED]â and â[REDACTED] - Proposal Documentâ appeared unremarkable and were not designed to provoke heightened emotions like typical social engineering or BEC attempts.</p><p>All emails had been given a Microsoft Spam Confidence Level of 1, indicating Microsoft did not consider them to be spam or malicious [2]. They also passed authentication checks (including SPF, and in some cases DKIM and DMARC), meaning they appeared to originate from an authentic source for the sender domain and had not been tampered with in transit. Â </p><p>All observed phishing emails contained a link hosted on a legitimate and commonly used file-sharing site. These sites were often convincingly themed, frequently featuring the name of a trusted vendor either on the page or within the URL, to appear authentic and avoid raising suspicion. However, these links served only as the initial step in a more complex, multi-stage phishing process.</p><p>â</p><figure style="max-width:904pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dbb274bc9297613e0b1f6a_Pasted%20Graphic%2014.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="A legitimate file sharing site used in phishing emails to host a secondary malicious link."/></div><figcaption>Figure 1: A legitimate file sharing site used in phishing emails to host a secondary malicious link.</figcaption></figure><figure style="max-width:1610pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dbb29bbb93d9548670ab44_YYR(G5)%20Date08132025%200740%20AM.png" loading="lazy" alt="Another example of a legitimate file sharing endpoint sent in a phishing email and used to host a malicious link."/></div><figcaption>Figure 2: Another example of a legitimate file sharing endpoint sent in a phishing email and used to host a malicious link.</figcaption></figure><p>If followed, the recipient would be redirected, sometimes via CAPTCHA, to fake Microsoft login pages designed to capturing credentials, namely http://pub-ac94c05b39aa4f75ad1df88d384932b8.r2[.]dev/offline[.]html and https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws[.]com/s3cure0line-0365cql0.19db86c3-b2b9-44cc-b339-36da233a3be2ml0qin/s3cccql0.19db86c3-b2b9-44cc-b339-36da233a3be2%26l0qn[.]html#. </p><p>The latter made use of homoglyphs to deceive the user, with a link referencing âs3cure0lineâ, rather than âsecureonlineâ. Post-incident investigation using open-source intelligence (OSINT) confirmed that the domains were linked to malicious phishing endpoints [3] [4]. </p><figure style="max-width:1032pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dbb2c43c7810d4c5603d9d_Sign%20in.png" loading="lazy" alt="Fake Microsoft login page designed to harvest credentials. "/></div><figcaption> Figure 3: Fake Microsoft login page designed to harvest credentials. </figcaption></figure><figure style="max-width:1590pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dbb2d959a9740dce483c27_SecureVault.png" loading="lazy" alt="Phishing kit with likely AI-generated image, designed to harvest user credentials. The URL uses âs3cure0lineâ instead of âsecureonlineâ, a subtle misspelling intended to deceive users."/></div><figcaption>Figure 4: Phishing kit with likely AI-generated image, designed to harvest user credentials. The URL uses âs3cure0lineâ instead of âsecureonlineâ, a subtle misspelling intended to deceive users.</figcaption></figure><h4><strong>Darktrace Anomaly Detection</strong></h4><p>Some senders were unknown to the network, with no previous outbound or inbound emails. Some had sent the email to multiple undisclosed recipients using BCC, an unusual behavior for a new sender. Â </p><p>Where the sender organization was an existing vendor, Darktrace recognized out-of-character behavior, in this case it was the first time a link to a particular file-sharing site had been shared. Often the links themselves exhibited anomalies, either being unusually prominent or hidden altogether - masked by text or a clickable image.</p><p>Crucially, <a href="/de/products/email">Darktrace / EMAIL</a> is able to identify malicious links at the time of processing the emails, without needing to visit the URLs or analyze the destination endpoints, meaning even the most convincing phishing pages cannot evade detection â meaning even the most convincing phishing emails cannot evade detection. This sets it apart from many competitors who rely on crawling the endpoints present in emails. This, among other things, risks disruption to user experience, such as unsubscribing them from emails, for instance.</p><p>Darktrace was also able to determine that the malicious emails originated from a compromised mailbox, using a series of behavioral and contextual metrics to make the identification. Upon analysis of the emails, Darktrace autonomously assigned several contextual tags to highlight their concerning elements, indicating that the messages contained phishing links, were likely sent from a compromised account, and originated from a known correspondent exhibiting out-of-character behavior. </p><figure style="max-width:901pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dbb3046bf7414701e9ef61_MODEL%20TAGS.png" loading="lazy" alt="A summary of the anomalous email, confirming that it contained a highly suspicious link."/></div><figcaption>Figure 5: Tags assigned to offending emails by Darktrace / EMAIL.</figcaption></figure><p>â</p><figure style="max-width:1590pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dbb3214756322d0d6d9c4e_ANOMALY%20INDICATORS.png" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption> Figure 6: A summary of the anomalous email, confirming that it contained a highly suspicious link.</figcaption></figure><h3>Out-of-character behavior caught in real-time</h3><p>In another customer environment around the same time Darktrace / EMAIL detected multiple emails with carefully crafted, contextually appropriate subject lines sent from an established correspondent being sent to 30 different recipients. In many cases, the attacker hijacked existing threads and inserted their malicious emails into an ongoing conversation in an effort to blend in and avoid detection. As in the previous, the attacker leveraged a well-known service, this time ClickFunnels, to host a document containing another malicious link. Once again, they were assigned a Microsoft Spam Confidence Level of 1, indicating that they were not considered malicious. </p><figure style="max-width:1610pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dbb347d189c8f016b663b8_You%20have%20been%20invited%20to%20access%20a%20file..png" loading="lazy" alt="The legitimate ClickFunnels page used to host a malicious phishing link."/></div><figcaption>Figure 7: The legitimate ClickFunnels page used to host a malicious phishing link.</figcaption></figure><p>This time, however, the customer had Darktrace / EMAIL fully enabled to take Autonomous Response against suspicious emails. As a result, when Darktrace detected the out-of-character behavior, specifically, the sharing of a link to a previously unused file-sharing domain, and identified the likely malicious intent of the message, it held the email, preventing it from reaching recipientsâ inboxes and effectively shutting down the attack.</p><figure style="max-width:1378pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dbb36567bd10f732c5ff81_unknown.jpg" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption>Figure 8: Darktrace / EMAILâs detection of malicious emails inserted into an existing thread.*</figcaption></figure><p><em>*To preserve anonymity, all real customer names, email addresses, and other identifying details have been redacted and replaced with fictitious placeholders.</em></p><p>Legitimate messages in the conversation were assigned an Anomaly Score of 0, while the newly inserted malicious emails identified and were flagged with the maximum score of 100.</p><h2><strong>Key takeaways for defenders</strong></h2><p>Phishing remains big business, and as the landscape evolves, todayâs campaigns often look very different from earlier versions. As with network-based attacks, threat actors are increasingly leveraging legitimate tools and exploiting trusted relationships to carry out their malicious goals, often staying under the radar of security teams and traditional email defenses.</p><p>As attackers continue to exploit trusted relationships between organizations and their third-party associates, security teams must remain vigilant to unexpected or suspicious email activity. Protecting the digital estate requires an email solution capable of identifying malicious characteristics, even when they originate from otherwise trusted senders.</p><p><em>Credit to Jennifer Beckett (Cyber Analyst), Patrick Anjos (Senior Cyber Analyst), Ryan Traill (Analyst Content Lead), Kiri Addison (Director of Product)</em></p><h2><strong>Appendices </strong></h2><h4>IoC - Type - Description + Confidence Â </h4><p>- http://pub-ac94c05b39aa4f75ad1df88d384932b8.r2[.]dev/offline[.]html#p â fake Microsoft login page</p><p> - https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws[.]com/s3cure0line-0365cql0.19db86c3-b2b9-44cc-b339-36da233a3be2ml0qin/s3cccql0.19db86c3-b2b9-44cc-b339-36da233a3be2%26l0qn[.]html# - link to domain used in homoglyph attack</p><h4>MITRE ATT&amp;CK Mapping Â </h4><h5>Tactic â Technique â Sub-Technique Â  </h5><p>Initial Access - Phishing â (T1566) Â </p><h4>References</h4><p>1. Â  Â  <a href="https://gitnux.org/third-party-risk-statistics/">https://gitnux.org/third-party-risk-statistics/</a></p><p>2. Â  Â  <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-office-365/anti-spam-spam-confidence-level-scl-about">https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-office-365/anti-spam-spam-confidence-level-scl-about</a> </p><p>3. Â  Â  <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/url/5df9aae8f78445a590f674d7b64c69630c1473c294ce5337d73732c03ab7fca2/detection">https://www.virustotal.com/gui/url/5df9aae8f78445a590f674d7b64c69630c1473c294ce5337d73732c03ab7fca2/detection</a></p><p>4. Â  Â  <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/url/695d0d173d1bd4755eb79952704e3f2f2b87d1a08e2ec660b98a4cc65f6b2577/details">https://www.virustotal.com/gui/url/695d0d173d1bd4755eb79952704e3f2f2b87d1a08e2ec660b98a4cc65f6b2577/details</a> </p><p><sup>The content provided in this blog is published by Darktrace for general informational purposes only and reflects our understanding of cybersecurity topics, trends, incidents, and developments at the time of publication. While we strive to ensure accuracy and relevance, the information is provided âas isâ without any representations or warranties, express or implied. Darktrace makes no guarantees regarding the completeness, accuracy, reliability, or timeliness of any information presented and expressly disclaims all warranties.</sup></p><p><sup>Nothing in this blog constitutes legal, technical, or professional advice, and readers should consult qualified professionals before acting on any information contained herein. Any references to third-party organizations, technologies, threat actors, or incidents are for informational purposes only and do not imply affiliation, endorsement, or recommendation.</sup></p><p><sup>Darktrace, its affiliates, employees, or agents shall not be held liable for any loss, damage, or harm arising from the use of or reliance on the information in this blog.</sup></p><p><sup>The cybersecurity landscape evolves rapidly, and blog content may become outdated or superseded. We reserve the right to update, modify, or remove any content</sup></p></div><a href="/de/blog/out-of-character-detecting-vendor-compromise-and-trusted-relationship-abuse-with-darktrace" class="horizontal align-center _20-column-gap hover-orange-underline w-inline-block"><div class="text-size-regular bold dark-orange">Continue reading</div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/6439504aac7642d452f73227_Orrange%20Arrow.svg" loading="eager" alt="" class="glossary-item-orange-arrow show"/></a></div><div id="w-node-d1366120-05a2-bfd5-a9b0-2be9d20c7ad6-c9d8d661" class="vertical align-left"><div class="heading-style-h6">About the author</div><div class="spacer-medium"></div><div class="horizontal _20-col-gap"><img src="" loading="lazy" alt="" class="_80-square new-box-shadow w-condition-invisible w-dyn-bind-empty"/><div><div class="text-size-large w-dyn-bind-empty"></div><div class="spacer-xsmall"></div><div class="text-eyebrow w-dyn-bind-empty"></div></div></div></div></div></div><div role="listitem" class="w-dyn-item"><div class="padding-section-small"><div class="blog-header"><div id="w-node-_6a4e4cbc-bd07-c860-591e-a3d80472f974-c9d8d661" class="blog-header-title"><div><div><div class="pixel-eyebrow_wrapper"><div class="icon-embed-custom w-embed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="100%" height="100%" viewBox="0 0 8 8" fill="none" preserveAspectRatio="xMidYMid meet" aria-hidden="true" role="img">
<rect width="8" height="8" fill="currentColor"/>
</svg></div><h2 class="text-eyebrow">Blog</h2><div class="text-eyebrow">/</div><h2 class="text-eyebrow">OT</h2><div class="text-eyebrow">/</div><h2 class="text-eyebrow">October 1, 2025</h2><div class="eyebrow-reveal-div"></div></div><div class="spacer-small"></div></div></div><h2 class="heading-style-h2">Announcing Unified OT Security with Dedicated OT Workflows, Segmentation-Aware Risk Insights, and Next-Gen Endpoint Visibility for Industrial Teams</h2></div><div id="w-node-_2561d5d9-fcb0-d673-7045-e0de5fb2172b-c9d8d661" class="blog-image-post-wrapper margin-0"><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc3d2d89fcfe728553eb4c_Teamwork%20on%20computer.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="" sizes="100vw" srcset="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc3d2d89fcfe728553eb4c_Teamwork%20on%20computer-p-500.jpg 500w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc3d2d89fcfe728553eb4c_Teamwork%20on%20computer.jpg 800w" class="blog-header-image cover"/><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/62d845d8a4c357036c43d980_Blog%20Post%20Image.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="Default blog image" class="blog-header-image cover w-condition-invisible"/><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/62ad3aca1401273fd522699d_Photo.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="Default blog image" class="blog-header-image cover w-condition-invisible"/><div class="blog-image-overlay max-height-300"></div></div></div></div><div class="blog-article-grid"><div class="vertical align-left max-w-720 bottom-padding-40 bottom-border-grey"><div class="text-rich-text truncate is-blog w-richtext"><h2>The challenge of convergence without clarity </h2><p>Convergence is no longer a roadmap idea, it is the daily reality for industrial security teams. As Information Technology (IT) and Operational Technology (OT) environments merge, the line between a cyber incident and an operational disruption grows increasingly hard to define. A misconfigured firewall rule can lead to downtime. A protocol misuse might look like a glitch. And when a pump stalls but nothing appears in the Security Operations Center (SOC) dashboard, teams are left asking: <em>is this operational or is this a threat</em>? </p><p>The lack of shared context slows down response, creates friction between SOC analysts and plant engineers, and leaves organizations vulnerable at exactly the points where IT and OT converge. Defenders need more than alerts, they need clarity that both sides can trust. </p><h2>The breakthrough with Darktrace / OT </h2><p>This latest Darktrace / OT release was built to deliver exactly that. It introduces shared context between Security, IT, and OT operations, helping reduce friction and close the security gaps at the intersection of these domains. </p><p>With a dedicated dashboard built for operations teams, extended visibility into endpoints for new forms of detection and CVE collection, expanded protocol coverage, and smarter risk modeling aligned to segmentation policies, teams can now operate from a shared source of truth. These enhancements are not just incremental upgrades, they are foundational improvements designed to bring clarity, efficiency, and trust to converged environments. </p><h2>A dashboard built for OT engineers </h2><p>The new <strong>Operational Overview</strong> provides OT engineers with a workspace designed for them, not for SOC analysts. It brings asset management, risk insights and operational alerts into one place. Engineers can now see activity like firmware changes, controller reprograms or the sudden appearance of a new workstation on the network, providing a tailored view for critical insights and productivity gains without navigating IT-centric workflows. Each device view is now enriched with cross-linked intelligence, make, model, firmware version and the roles inferred by Self-Learning AI, making it easier to understand how each asset behaves, what function it serves, and where it fits within the broader industrial process. By suppressing IT-centric noise, the dashboard highlights only the anomalies that matter to operations, accelerating triage, enabling smoother IT/OT collaboration, and reducing time to root cause without jumping between tools. </p><p>This is usability with purpose, a view that matches OT workflows and accelerates response. </p><figure style="max-width:1986pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc3bee69898f20763f997d_Screenshot%202025-09-30%20at%201.21.47%E2%80%AFPM.png" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption>Figure 1: The Operational Overview provides an intuitive dashboard summarizing all OT Assets, Alerts, and Risk.</figcaption></figure><h2>Full-spectrum coverage across endpoints, sensors and protocols </h2><p>The release also extends visibility into areas that have traditionally been blind spots. Engineering workstations, Human-Machine Interfaces (HMIs), contractor laptops and field devices are often the entry points for attackers, yet the hardest to monitor. </p><p>Darktrace introduces <strong>Network Endpoint eXtended Telemetry (NEXT) for OT</strong>, a lightweight collector built for segmented and resource-constrained environments. NEXT for OT uses Endpoint sensors to capture localized network, and now process-level telemetry, placing it in context alongside other network and asset data to: </p><ol start="1" role="list"><li><strong>Identify vulnerabilities and OS data</strong>, which is leveraged by OT Risk Management for risk scoring and patching prioritization, removing the need for third-party CVE collection. </li></ol><ol start="2" role="list"><li><strong>Surface novel threats</strong> using Self-Learning AI that standalone Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) would miss. </li></ol><ol start="3" role="list"><li><strong>Extend Cyber AI Analyst investigations</strong> through to the endpoint root cause. </li></ol><p>NEXT is part of our existing cSensor endpoint agent, can be deployed standalone or alongside existing EDR tools, and allows capabilities to be enabled or disabled depending on factors such as security or OT team objectives and resource utilization. </p><figure style="max-width:1850pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc3c29be6e1da072bb0971_Screenshot%202025-09-30%20at%201.22.57%E2%80%AFPM.png" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption>Figure 2: Darktrace / OT delivers CVE patch priority insights by combining threat intelligence with extended network and endpoint telemetry</figcaption></figure><p>The family of Darktrace Endpoint sensors also receive a boost in deployment flexibility, with on-prem server-based setups, as well as a Windows driver tailored for zero-trust and high-security environments. </p><p>Protocol coverage has been extended where it matters most. Darktrace now performs protocol analysis of a wider range of <strong>GE</strong> and <strong>Mitsubishi</strong> protocols, giving operators real-time visibility into commands and state changes on Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs), robots and controllers. Backed by Self-Learning AI, this inspection does more than parse traffic, it understands what normal looks like and flags deviations that signal risk. </p><h2>Integrated risk and governance workflows </h2><p>Security data is only valuable when it drives action. Darktrace / OT delivers risk insights that go beyond patching, helping teams take meaningful steps even when remediation isn&#x27;t possible. Risk is assessed not just by CVE presence, but by how network segmentation, firewall policies, and attack path logic neutralize or contain real-world exposure. This approach empowers defenders to deprioritize low-impact vulnerabilities and focus effort where risk truly exists. Building on the foundation introduced in release 6.3, such as KEV enrichment, endpoint OS data, and exploit mapping, this release introduces new integrations that bring Darktrace / OT intelligence directly into governance workflows. <br/> <br/><strong>Fortinet FortiGate firewall ingestion</strong> feeds segmentation rules into attack path modeling, revealing real exposure when policies fail and closing feeds into patching prioritization based on a policy to CVE exposure assessment. </p><ul role="list"><li><strong>ServiceNow Configuration Management Database (CMDB) sync</strong> ensures asset intelligence stays current across governance platforms, eliminating manual inventory work. </li></ul><p>Risk modeling has also been made more operationally relevant. Scores are now contextualized by exploitability, asset criticality, firewall policy, and segmentation posture. Patch recommendations are modeled in terms of safety, uptime and compliance rather than just Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) numbers. And importantly, <strong>risk is prioritized across the Purdue Model</strong>, giving defenders visibility into whether vulnerabilities remain isolated to IT or extend into OT-critical layers. </p><figure style="max-width:1842pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc3c93d42cb52f2f848445_Screenshot%202025-09-30%20at%201.24.44%E2%80%AFPM.png" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption>Figure 3: Attack Path Modeling based on NetFlow and network topology reveals high risk points of IT/OT convergence. </figcaption></figure><h2>The real-world impact for defenders </h2><p>In todayâs environments, attackers move fluidly between IT and OT. Without unified visibility and shared context, incidents cascade faster than teams can respond. </p><p>With this release, Darktrace / OT changes that reality. The Operational Overview gives Engineers a dashboard they can use daily, tailored to their workflows. SOC analysts can seamlessly investigate telemetry across endpoints, sensors and protocols that were once blind spots. Operators gain transparency into PLCs and controllers. Governance teams benefit from automated integrations with platforms like Fortinet and ServiceNow. And all stakeholders work from risk models that reflect what truly matters: safety, uptime and compliance. </p><p>This release is not about creating more alerts. It is about providing more clarity. By unifying context across IT and OT, Darktrace / OT enables defenders to see more, understand more and act faster. </p><p>Because in environments where safety and uptime are non-negotiable, clarity is what matters most. </p><h3><a href="https://www.darktrace.com/event-hub/innovation-launch-cross-domain">Join us for our live event </a>where we will discuss these product innovations in greater detail</h3><figure style="max-width:1413pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><a href="https://www.darktrace.com/event-hub/innovation-launch-cross-domain" target="_blank" class="w-inline-block"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc095c9fd2e44c39fe97f9_Screenshot%202025-09-30%20at%2017.46.12.png" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div></a></figure></div><a href="/de/blog/darktrace-announces-unified-ot-security-introducing-dedicated-workflows-for-ot-engineers-segmentation-aware-risk-modeling-and-next-generation-endpoint-visibility-for-industrial-teams" class="horizontal align-center _20-column-gap hover-orange-underline w-inline-block"><div class="text-size-regular bold dark-orange">Continue reading</div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/6439504aac7642d452f73227_Orrange%20Arrow.svg" loading="eager" alt="" class="glossary-item-orange-arrow show"/></a></div><div id="w-node-d1366120-05a2-bfd5-a9b0-2be9d20c7ad6-c9d8d661" class="vertical align-left"><div class="heading-style-h6">About the author</div><div class="spacer-medium"></div><div class="horizontal _20-col-gap"><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68dc45685b280cda7da04e43_Screenshot%202025-09-30%20at%202.02.16%E2%80%AFPM.png" loading="lazy" alt="" sizes="100vw" <script>
const queryString = window.location.search;
  const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(queryString);
  const params = ['utm_campaign', 'utm_source', 'utm_content', 'utm_medium', 'utm_term', 'utm_id'];
  let url_additions = "";

  for (let param of params) {
    let paramData = urlParams.get(param) || localStorage.getItem(param) || "-";
    if (paramData) {
      if (paramData != "-") {
        url_additions += param + "=" + paramData + "&";
      }
      localStorage.setItem(param, paramData);

      // Select the form input by ID and set its value if it exists
      const inputElement = document.getElementById(param);
      if (inputElement) {
        inputElement.value = paramData;
      }
    }
  }

  url_additions = url_additions.slice(0, -1);  
  

const links = document.querySelectorAll('a');
links.forEach(link => {
    if ((link.href.includes('novalue') || link.href.includes('/virtual-innovation-launch')) && !link.href.includes('#')) {
        link.href = link.href + (link.href.includes('?') ? '&' : '?') + url_additions;
    }
});

"Sint Maarten", "code": "SX" }, { "name": "Bonaire, Saint Eustatius and Saba", "code": "BQ" }, { "name": "South Sudan", "code": "SS" }, { "name": "Serbia and Montenegro", "code": "CS" }, { "name": "Saint Barthelemy", "code": "BL" } ]

    for(var c = 0; c<countries.length; c++) {
            if(c == 0){
        $('[id^='+whereto+']').append('<option value>' + countries[c].name + '</option>');

            }else{
        $('[id^='+whereto+']').append('<option value="' + countries[c].code + '">' + countries[c].name + '</option>');
            }
    }
}
 function addStates(whereto) {
    let states = [
      { "name": "", "code": "none" },
      { "name": "Alabama", "code": "AL" }, { "name": "Alaska", "code": "AK" }, { "name": "Arizona", "code": "AZ" },
      { "name": "Arkansas", "code": "AR" }, { "name": "California", "code": "CA" }, { "name": "Colorado", "code": "CO" },
      { "name": "Connecticut", "code": "CT" }, { "name": "Delaware", "code": "DE" }, { "name": "Florida", "code": "FL" },
      { "name": "Georgia", "code": "GA" }, { "name": "Hawaii", "code": "HI" }, { "name": "Idaho", "code": "ID" },
      { "name": "Illinois", "code": "IL" }, { "name": "Indiana", "code": "IN" }, { "name": "Iowa", "code": "IA" },
      { "name": "Kansas", "code": "KS" }, { "name": "Kentucky", "code": "KY" }, { "name": "Louisiana", "code": "LA" },
      { "name": "Maine", "code": "ME" }, { "name": "Maryland", "code": "MD" }, { "name": "Massachusetts", "code": "MA" },
      { "name": "Michigan", "code": "MI" }, { "name": "Minnesota", "code": "MN" }, { "name": "Mississippi", "code": "MS" },
      { "name": "Missouri", "code": "MO" }, { "name": "Montana", "code": "MT" }, { "name": "Nebraska", "code": "NE" },
      { "name": "Nevada", "code": "NV" }, { "name": "New Hampshire", "code": "NH" }, { "name": "New Jersey", "code": "NJ" },
      { "name": "New Mexico", "code": "NM" }, { "name": "New York", "code": "NY" }, { "name": "North Carolina", "code": "NC" },
      { "name": "North Dakota", "code": "ND" }, { "name": "Ohio", "code": "OH" }, { "name": "Oklahoma", "code": "OK" },
      { "name": "Oregon", "code": "OR" }, { "name": "Pennsylvania", "code": "PA" }, { "name": "Rhode Island", "code": "RI" },
      { "name": "South Carolina", "code": "SC" }, { "name": "South Dakota", "code": "SD" }, { "name": "Tennessee", "code": "TN" },
      { "name": "Texas", "code": "TX" }, { "name": "Utah", "code": "UT" }, { "name": "Vermont", "code": "VT" },
      { "name": "Virginia", "code": "VA" }, { "name": "Washington", "code": "WA" }, { "name": "West Virginia", "code": "WV" },
      { "name": "Wisconsin", "code": "WI" }, { "name": "Wyoming", "code": "WY" }
    ];
    
    // Populate the state dropdown
    for (var c = 0; c < states.length; c++) {
      if (c == 0) {
        $('[id=' + whereto + ']').append('<option value="-" selected>' + states[c].name + '</option>');
      } else {
        $('[id=' + whereto + ']').append('<option value="' + states[c].code + '">' + states[c].name + '</option>');
      }
    }
  }

  // Add states to any select with ID 'state' by default
  addStates('state');
  addCountries('country');

  // Function to handle change in country selection
  function handleCountryChange(event) {
    const countryValue = event.target.value;
    const stateElements = document.querySelectorAll('#state, [id$="-State"]'); // Selects all states including generic and form specific
    const stateBlockElements = document.querySelectorAll('#state-block, [id$="-State-Block"]'); // Selects all state blocks

    if (countryValue === "US") {
      stateBlockElements.forEach(element => element.style.display = "block");
      stateElements.forEach(element => element.value = null);
    } else {
      stateBlockElements.forEach(element => element.style.display = "none");
      stateElements.forEach(element => {
        element.required = false;
        element.selectedIndex = 0;
        element.value = "-";
      });
    }
  }

  // Attach event listener to any country dropdowns with ID 'country' or ending with '-Country'
  document.querySelectorAll('#country, [id$="-Country"]').forEach(countryElement => {
    countryElement.addEventListener('change', handleCountryChange);
  });

  // Webflow specific code to add states to forms listed in the array
  let forms = [
    "Start-Free-Trial", "Main-Form", "Nav-Get-a-Demo", "Primary-CTA-Free-Trial", 
    "Primary-CTA-Get-a-Demo", "Contact-Page", "Featured-Resource", "Whitepaper-Resource", 
    "Resource-Page", "Specific-Event-Form", "Specific-Resource"
  ];

  Webflow.push(function () {
    forms.forEach(form => {
      addCountries(form + "-Country");
      addStates(form + "-State");
    });
  });

  // Attach event listeners to all country dropdowns related to the forms listed
  forms.forEach((form) => {
    const countrySelector = `#${form}-Country`;
    document.querySelectorAll(countrySelector).forEach(countryElement => {
      countryElement.addEventListener("change", handleCountryChange);
    });
  });
var form = document.getElementById("main_form_2");
var url = window.location.pathname;
if (form){
  var field = form.querySelector("#Message");
  if(url === "/contact") {
    field.classList.remove('hidden')
  }else{
    field.value = "-"
    console.log("field.value", field.value)
  }
}

$('#current_url').val(window.location.pathname);
  
</script>

<script>
  const now = new Date();
  const dateTimeString = now.toISOString();
  $('form').each(function() {
   for (let param of params) {
    let paramData = urlParams.get(param) || localStorage.getItem(param) || "-";
 
     $(this).append($('<input>').attr({
      type: 'hidden',
      name: param,
      value: paramData
    }));
    
}
    $(this).append($('<input>').attr({
      type: 'hidden',
      name: 'currentDateTime',
      value: dateTimeString
    }));
    
    const formId = $(this).find('#form-identifier').attr('data-id');
    if(formId){
      $(this).append($('<input>').attr({
        type: 'hidden',
        name: 'form_id',
        value: formId
      }));
    }
  });
  
$('.form-label.focus-in').removeClass('focus-in');

$('.text-input, .select-field').on('focusin', function() {
  $(this).siblings('.form-label').addClass('focus-in');
});

$('.text-input, .select-field').on('focusout change', function() {
  $(this).siblings('.form-label').toggleClass('focus-in', $(this).val() !== '');
});
</script>
<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/gsap/3.11.4/gsap.min.js"></script>

<script>
let menuLink = $(".nav-dropdown-link");
let content = $(".nav-hover-2");
let menuBG = $(".nav-menu-bg-2");
let dropdownWrap = $(".nav-content-2");
let menuArrow = $(".nav-arrow-wrap");
content.hide()
menuBG.css("overflow","hidden");

gsap.defaults({
  duration: .3
});

function revealDropdown(currentLink, currentContent) {
  dropdownWrap.css("display", "flex");
  gsap.set(menuArrow, {
    width: currentLink.outerWidth(),
    x: currentLink.offset().left
  });
  gsap.set(menuBG, {
    width: currentContent.outerWidth(),
    height: currentContent.outerHeight()
  });
  gsap.set(content, {
    opacity: 0
  });
  gsap.set(currentContent, {
    opacity: 1,
    x: "0em"
  });
}

function switchDropdown(currentLink, previousContent, currentContent) { 
  gsap.to(menuArrow, {
    width: currentLink.outerWidth(),
    x: currentLink.offset().left
  });
  gsap.to(menuBG, {
    width: currentContent.outerWidth(),
    height: currentContent.outerHeight()
  });
  // invert moveDistance if needed
  let moveDistance = 10;
  if (currentContent.index() < previousContent.index()) {
    moveDistance = moveDistance * -1;
  }
  gsap.fromTo(
    previousContent,
    { opacity: 1, x: "0em" },
    {
      opacity: 0,
      x: moveDistance * -1 + "em",
      duration: .15,
        onComplete: () => {
            previousContent.hide()
        }
    }
  );
  gsap.fromTo(
    currentContent,
    { opacity: 0, x: moveDistance + "em" },
    {
      opacity: 1,
      x: "0em",
      duration: .15
    }
  );
}

let showDropdown = gsap.timeline({
  paused: true,
  onReverseComplete: () => {
    dropdownWrap.css("display", "none");
    menuLink.removeClass("active");
  }
});
showDropdown.from(dropdownWrap, { opacity: 0, rotateX: -10, duration: 0.2 }).to(menuArrow, { opacity: 1, duration: 0.2 }, "<");

menuLink.on("mouseenter", function () {
  menuBG.show()
  let previousLink = menuLink.filter(".active").removeClass("active");
  let currentLink = $(this).addClass("active");
  let previousContent = content.filter(".active").removeClass("active");
  let currentContent = content.eq($(this).index()).addClass("active");

    if(previousContent.length > 0 && currentContent[0] != previousContent[0]){
      setTimeout(function() {
        previousContent.hide();
      }, 150);
    }
	currentContent.show()

  showDropdown.play();
  if (previousLink.length === 0) {
    revealDropdown(currentLink, currentContent);
  } else if (previousLink.index() !== currentLink.index()) {
    switchDropdown(currentLink, previousContent, currentContent);
  }
});

$(".primary-nav-links").on("mouseleave", function () {
  showDropdown.reverse();
});

</script>
<script>
        // List of blocked email domains
        const blockedDomains = [
            "gmail.com",
  "hotmail.com",
  "yahoo.com",
  "outlook.com",
  "icloud.com",
  "protonmail.com",
  "qq.com",
  "163.com",
  "me.com",
  "comcast.net",
  "aol.com",
  "hotmail.co.uk",
  "yahoo.co.uk",
  "live.com",
  "mail.com",
  "email.com",
  "msn.com",
  "yahoo.fr",
  "naver.com",
  "gmx.com",
  "mail.ru",
  "verizon.net",
  "ymail.com",
  "hotmail.fr",
  "artlover.com",
  "btinternet.com",
  "att.net",
  "orange.fr",
  "yandex.com",
  "googlemail.com",
  "bk.ru",
  "web.de",
  "yandex.ru",
  "outlook.fr",
  "rambler.ru",
  "free.fr",
  "wp.pl",
  "foxmail.com",
  "hotmail.it",
  "wanadoo.fr",
  "t-online.de",
  "live.co.uk",
  "my.com",
  "yahoo.co.in",
  "live.fr",
  "live.nl",
  "rocketmail.com",
  "yahoo.ca",
  "tom.com",
  "libero.it",
  "yeah.net",
  "139.com",
  "hotmail.de",
  "temple.edu",
  "earthlink.net",
  "rediffmail.com",
  "live.com.au",
  "hotmail.ca",
  "yahoo.gr",
  "yahoo.it",
  "yahoo.com.au",
  "yahoo.com.br",
  "virginmedia.com",
  "fastmail.com",
  "sudomail.com",
  "talktalk.net",
  "yaho.com",
  "yahoo.es",
  "myself.com",
  "outlook.pt",
  "live.cl",
  "windstream.net",
  "ya.ru",
  "yahoo.com.sg",
  "hanmail.net",
  "gmx.at",
  "fake.com",
  "outlook.de",
  "gmx.fr",
  "yahoo.com.tw",
  "live.ie",
  "hotmail.nl",
  "hotmail.be",
  "outlook.co.id",
  "gmx.net",
  "yahoo.de",
  "fastmail.fm",
  "mydomain.com",
  "mailbox.org",
  "sprintmail.com",
  "outlook.it",
  "gmx.co.uk",
  "outlook.jp",
  "list.ru",
  "live.ca",
  "live.de",
  "gmail.ru",
  "mail.fr",
  "operamail.com",
  "africamail.com",
  "live.dk"
        ];

        // Function to check if an email belongs to a blocked domain
        function isBlockedDomain(email) {
            const domain = email.split('@')[1];
            return blockedDomains.includes(domain);
        }

        // Function to handle email input
        function handleEmailInput(event) {
            const email = event.target.value;
            const errorMessage = event.target.nextElementSibling;
            if (isBlockedDomain(email)) {
                errorMessage.style.display = 'block';
                event.target.setCustomValidity('Please use a business email.');
            } else {
                errorMessage.style.display = 'none';
                event.target.setCustomValidity('');
            }
        }

        // Function to handle form submission
        function handleFormSubmission(event) {
            const emailInputs = event.target.querySelectorAll('input[type="email"]');
            let formIsValid = true;
            emailInputs.forEach(input => {
                const email = input.value;
                if (isBlockedDomain(email)) {
                    const errorMessage = input.nextElementSibling;
                    errorMessage.style.display = 'block';
                    formIsValid = false;
                }
            });
            if (!formIsValid) {
                event.preventDefault();
            }
        }

        // Attach event listeners to all email inputs and forms on the page
        document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {
            const emailInputs = document.querySelectorAll('input[type="email"]');
            emailInputs.forEach(input => {
                // Create an error message element
                const errorMessage = document.createElement('div');
                errorMessage.className = 'error-message';
                errorMessage.textContent = 'Please use a business email';
                input.insertAdjacentElement('afterend', errorMessage);

                // Add event listener
                input.addEventListener('input', handleEmailInput);
            });

            // Attach submit event listener to all forms
            const forms = document.querySelectorAll('form');
            forms.forEach(form => {
                form.addEventListener('submit', handleFormSubmission);
            });
        });
</script>


<script>
function updateLink(containerId, newHref) {
    const container = document.getElementById(containerId);
    if (container) {
        const dropdownToggle = container.querySelector('.navbar12_dropdown-toggle');
        if (dropdownToggle) {
            // Create a new anchor element
            const newLink = document.createElement('a');
            newLink.href = newHref;
            
            // Copy attributes from the dropdown toggle to the new link
            for (let i = 0; i < dropdownToggle.attributes.length; i++) {
                const attr = dropdownToggle.attributes[i];
                newLink.setAttribute(attr.name, attr.value);
            }
            
            // Copy the inner content
            newLink.innerHTML = dropdownToggle.innerHTML;
            
            // Replace the dropdown toggle with the new link
            dropdownToggle.parentNode.replaceChild(newLink, dropdownToggle);
        }
    }
}

// Call the function for each link
updateLink('products-link', '/products');
updateLink('resource-link', '/resources');
updateLink('company-link', '/company');
updateLink('partner-link', '/partners');
</script>


<script>
  // This script adds rel="noopener noreferrer" to all external links that open in a new tab (target="_blank")
  // Internal links (same domain) are excluded.

  document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function () {
    const links = document.querySelectorAll('a[target="_blank"]');
    const currentHostname = window.location.hostname;

    links.forEach(link => {
      try {
        const linkHostname = new URL(link.href).hostname;

        // Skip if the link is internal
        if (linkHostname === currentHostname) return;

        // Get existing rel attribute or set to empty string
        let rel = link.getAttribute('rel') || '';

        // Add 'noopener' if not present
        if (!rel.includes('noopener')) rel += ' noopener';

        // Add 'noreferrer' if not present
        if (!rel.includes('noreferrer')) rel += ' noreferrer';

        // Set the updated rel attribute
        link.setAttribute('rel', rel.trim());
      } catch (e) {
        // Handle invalid URLs (e.g., mailto links)
        console.warn('Invalid URL:', link.href);
      }
    });
  });
</script>




<p id="twitter-share-text" fs-socialshare-element="content" style="display: none;">Check out this article by Darktrace: Emotet Revival: Tactics and Mitigations</p>



<script>
   
  function shareToLinkedIn(btn, link) {
    btn.setAttribute('target', '_blank');
    btn.setAttribute(
        'href',
        `https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=${link}`
    );
    btn.setAttribute('rel', 'noreferrer noopener');
}

    function socialShare(platform, btn, link) {
         if (platform === 'facebook') {
             shareToFacebook(btn, link);
         } else if (platform === 'twitter') {
             shareToTwitter(btn, link);
         } else if (platform === 'linkedin') {
             shareToLinkedIn(btn, link);
         }
     
    }
    
    // social sharing
    const btns = {
        'linkedin': document.querySelector('[data-social="linkedin"]'),
        'twitter': document.querySelector('[data-social="twitter"]')
    }

    const link = window.location.href;

    for (let key in btns) {
        if (btns.hasOwnProperty(key)) {
            socialShare(key, btns[key], link);
        }
    }
    
   </script>

<script>
document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", function () {
    function insertCTA(retries = 0) {
        let blogCta = document.querySelector('.blog-cta-report');
        if (!blogCta) {
            if (retries < 5) { // Prevents infinite retry loops
                console.warn(`CTA element not found. Retrying... (${retries + 1}/5)`);
                setTimeout(() => insertCTA(retries + 1), 500);
            } else {
                console.error("CTA element not found after multiple attempts.");
            }
            return;
        }

        // Hide the original CTA so it doesn't appear twice
        blogCta.style.display = 'none';

        document.querySelectorAll('.text-rich-text.is-blog').forEach(block => {
            let placeholders = [...block.getElementsByTagName("p")].filter(p => p.textContent.includes("[related-resource]")); // Uses textContent for security

            // Limit to inserting only 2 CTAs if multiple placeholders exist
            placeholders.slice(0, 2).forEach(placeholder => {
                let clonedCTA = blogCta.cloneNode(true);
                clonedCTA.style.removeProperty('display');
                clonedCTA.style.removeProperty('visibility');
                clonedCTA.classList.remove("w-condition-invisible");
                clonedCTA.classList.add("w-condition-visible");

                placeholder.replaceWith(clonedCTA);
            });
        });
    }

    // Run after Webflow scripts initialize
    window.Webflow ||= [];
    window.Webflow.push(insertCTA);
});
</script>


<script>
window.
dataLayer = window.
dataLayer || [];
window.
dataLayer.push({
'event': 'content_grouping',
'content_group': ['']
});
</script>
<script src="https://hubspotonwebflow.com/assets/js/form-124.js" type="text/javascript" integrity="sha384-bjyNIOqAKScdeQ3THsDZLGagNN56B4X2Auu9YZIGu+tA/PlggMk4jbWruG/P6zYj" crossorigin="anonymous"></script></body></html>
